metadata.title: Mononuclear iron-dependent electrocatalytic activity of metal-nitrogen-carbon catalysts for efficient oxygen reduction reaction

Fig. 1 Illustration for the preparation procedure of the mononuclear iron catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 TEM images of the mononuclear iron catalysts prepared at different pyrolysis temperature, (A) 700 ℃; (B) 800 ℃; (C) 900 ℃ and (D) 1000 ℃. (Insets: the corresponding HRTEM images). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (A) XRD patterns, (B) Raman and (C) partial enlarged Raman spectra of the mononuclear iron catalysts fabricated at different temperature. (D) High-resolution XPS spectra of the N 1s and its related curved-fitted components of the catalysts. (N1, N2, N3 refers to pyridinic, pyrrolic and graphitic N, respectively). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (A) RDE polarization curves of the mononuclear Fe catalysts fabricated at different temperature and a commercial Pt/C (20 wt% Pt) in O2-saturated 1 M NaOH solution with a sweep rate of 5 mV s-1 and a rotation rate of 1600 rpm; (B) The half-wave potentials of the above catalysts; (C) The mass-specific activities at 0.9 V vs. RHE; (D) Tafel plots at the low overpotential region. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (A) The RRDE polarization curves of these catalysts in O2-saturated 1 M NaOH solution; (B) The calculated peroxide yield and electron transfer number (n); (C) Chronoaperometric response of the Cat-800 and Pt/C at 0.7 V (vs. RHE); (D) Current loss ratio during the chronoapermetric test. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (A) The Fourier transform at the Fe K-edge of EXAFS spectra of the mononuclear iron catalysts fabricated at different temperature (700, 800, 900 and 1000℃); (B) The corresponding Fe K-edge XANES spectra (the insets is a schematic illustration of the nonplanar structure of the FeN4 groups); (C) XPS spectra of the Co 2p of these catalysts; (D) The corresponding Fe L-edge XANES spectra. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (A) relationship between half-wave potential and content of the covalent FeN4 groups; (B) correlation between mass specific activity (MSA) and content of the covalent FeN bonds. Fig. 7 Table 1 Contents of various types of nitrogen sites in the mononuclear Fe catalysts fabricated different temperature, determined by XPS. Table 1 Sample N(at%) Pyridinic-N(%) Pyrrolic-N(%) Graphitic-N(%) Fe-N(%) 700 6.9 22.3 28.4 30.6 18.7 800 4.5 27.3 26.5 24.6 21.6 900 2.8 19.5 36.6 29.9 13.9 1000 2.5 6.9 42.7 42.9 7.5 Mononuclear iron-dependent electrocatalytic activity of metal-nitrogen-carbon catalysts for efficient oxygen reduction reaction Min Liu Jingjun Liu ⁎ Ye Song Zhilin Li Feng Wang ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering, Beijing Key Laboratory of Electrochemical Process and Technology for Materials, Beijing University of Chemical Technology, Beijing 100029, PR China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Resource Engineering Beijing Key Laboratory of Electrochemical Process and Technology for Materials Beijing University of Chemical Technology Beijing 100029 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract As a low-cost nonprecious metal-based catalyst, the mononuclear iron embedded in nitrogen-doped carbons has been regarded as one type of the best electrocatalytic materials for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Herein, we proposed a silica-protective-layer assisted strategy for fabricating the catalysts with mononuclear iron site coordinated with adjacent nitrogen and carbon atoms, through high temperature pyrolysis of melamine, carbon black and FeCl3. At 800 °C, the fabricated catalyst features completely atomic level iron-nitrogen-carbon catalysts without Fe-based phases. In concentrated 1 M NaOH solution, this catalyst displays a remarkably improved catalytic activity with half-wave potential of 0.90 V. The mass activity of catalyst can reach 1.06 times that of commercial Pt/C (20 wt%, Pt). The correlation of the mononuclear iron composition and coordination structure with the promoted ORR kinetics was discussed in detail. The superior activity can be attributed to lots of the mononuclear iron moieties with a non-planar Fe(II)-N4 structure and increased surface area of the as-synthesized heterogeneous catalyst. Keywords Mononuclear iron catalysts Silica template Pyrolysis temperature Non-planar Fe(II)-N4 structure Oxygen reduction reaction 1 Introduction To overcome the challenges of environmental pollution and depletion of fossil energy, it is required to develop a wide range of renewable energy technologies, such as fuel cells [1], metal-air batteries [2]. For these above clean energy systems, one of the major cornerstones is that the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is a sluggish kinetic. To date, Platinum (Pt) and Pt-based alloys have been considered as the most efficient catalysts for the ORR. However, their scare reserve, high cost, poor durability, and low poison resistance significantly prohibit the practical application. To overcome these obstacles, tremendous efforts are being devoted to developing an efficient electrocatalyst based on earth-abundant elements, including C, N, Co, or Fe [3–6]. Among these nonprecious catalysts, iron and nitrogen co-doped carbon is a promising candidate because of its superior activity and electrochemical stability toward the ORR [7–9]. In 1960′s, Jasinski initially studied the mononuclear cobalt catalysts with cobalt centered macrocyclic compounds [10]. After this study, numerous materials with a Fe site coordinated to four adjacent nitrogen atoms (Fe-N4) have been widely synthesized as non-precious metal catalysts for the ORR [11–13]. In the Fe-N4 configuration, the metal is mononuclear Fe ion, which presents two oxidation states, low-spin Fe(II) and high-spin Fe(III) [8,14]. In recent years, a growing body of literature based on spectroscopic studies suggests that the low-spin Fe(II)-N4 moieties with unfilled dz2 orbitals can contribute to the chemical adsorption of O2 molecules, which have been reported as the primarily active sites for reducing O2 [15–20]. Then, the mononuclear Fe (II) central sites undergoes Fe(II)/Fe(III) redox transition and the lost electron will be gained by the absorbed O2, leading a weakened OO bond and promoting the initiation step of the oxygen reduction process [21,22]. In contrast, the mononuclear Fe (III) ions are inactive sites for the ORR. Thus, it may be an effective strategy to obtain the mononuclear Fe (II) sites instead of inactive phases by using silica as a protective material during the pyrolysis. For example, Pylypenko first reported that the silica-assisted iron catalyst had shown considerably high catalytic activity for ORR [23]. Meanwhile, the silica-protected layer can maintain the physical and chemical integrity even at high temperature, avoiding the formation of multinuclear iron phases [24]. Furthermore, during the design of the electrocatalysts on mononuclear iron catalyst, Liang suggest that the SiO2 layer can facilitate the coordination between nitrogen atoms and the mononuclear Fe (II) to form unique Fe(II)-N4 species, preventing the agglomeration of iron species [25]. Therefore, the unique physical and chemical properties of silica can greatly motivated extensive interests in synthesizing the mononuclear Fe heterogeneous catalysts without impurities. In our previous work [26], the silica plays a crucial role in the formation of the completely atomic level Fe-N-C catalysts, which is used as a space-confined template. This synthesis method can avoid the formation of Fe-based impurity phases. The as-synthesized Fe-N-C catalysts display a remarkably enhanced ORR activity, relative to a commercial Pt/C catalyst. However, the effect of different pyrolysis temperatures of melamine on embedding behaviors of Fe atoms into carbon matrix remains unclear. It needs to further understand how the pyrolysis temperature control the chemical structures and valence state of the embedded iron atoms in the catalysts containing nitrogen and carbon atoms, which may governor ORR activity. So, this work may highlight the formation process of the Fe-N-C catalysts and can open a path for rationally designing mononuclear iron-based electrocatalysts. 1.1 Experimental section 1.1.1 Materials preparation Mononuclear Fe ion embedded in nitrogen-doped carbon is synthesized as following steps. In brief, prior to SiO2 coating, a carbon black (Vulcan XC-72, Cabot) was modified with nitric acid to improve the dispersion of carbon black in aqueous solution and the affinity to positive ions. After the surface modification, 0.1 g pre-acid-treated carbon black was added to 20 ml ethanol solution and stirred by a magnetic bar at room temperature. Once the carbon black was uniformly dispersed, 0.1 g melamine and 5 mL FeCl3 solution (0.18 M) were added into the solution and stirred for overnight to make sure that the Fe3+ ions and melamine can be evenly absorbed on the surface of carbon matrix through electrostatic interaction. Then the mixture was pre-heated to 250 ℃ in a quartz-tube furnace at a ramp of 5 ℃ min−1 and held at that temperature for 1 h under Argon (Ar) gas. The pre-treated hybrids was subsequently mixed with 2 mL tetraethyl orthosilicate in an agate mortar, followed by adding 2 mL formic acid and drying at 80 ℃ to form a well-distributed silica layer. Then the silica-protected hybrids was placed in an alumina crucible, heated to 800 ℃ at a ramping rate of 5 ℃min-1 and maintained at this temperature for 1 h with an inert Ar gas environment. Finally, the resulting mononuclear Fe heterogeneous catalyst was stirred with 3:1 (v/v)=ehanol:10% HF solution at room temperature for 2 h to remove the silica layer, followed by filtering and washing with ethanol and water several times until the filtrate became neutral and then dried at 80 ℃. According to the pyrolysis temperature, the obtained catalysts are denoted as Cat-700, Cat-800, Cat-900 and Cat-1000. 1.1.2 Materials characterization Structure and morphology of the as-synthesized catalysts are characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku RINT 2200 V/PC, Cu Kα), Raman spectroscopy (LabRam HR800) with a visible laser (λ = 532 nm) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM 2100, 120 kV). Surface characterization of the mononuclear Fe catalysts was performed using an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Thermo ESCALAB 250). To determine the exact structure and electronic state of mononuclear Fe site in the carbon, X-ray absorption spectroscopy at Fe k-edge was conducted at the 1W1B beamline of Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory. 1.1.3 Electrochemical measurements ORR performance is evaluated in 1 M NaOH solution using a glassy carbon rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE, 5.61 mm of disk outer diameter, Pine Research Instrumentation, USA). The catalyst ink was prepared by mixing 5 mg of the catalyst powder with 20 μL of Nafion solution (5% wt.) and 1 mL of ethanol. The ink was sonicated for over 30 min to achieve a good dispersion. 20 μL of the catalyst ink was dropped on the glassy carbon surface, resulting in a catalyst loading on the electrode of 0.4 mg cm−2. As a comparison, a commercial Pt/C (20 wt% Pt, E-TEK) was also tested and the loading on the electrode is 0.1 mg cm−2. A saturated calomel electrode (SCE) and a graphitic rod were used as the reference and the counter electrode, respectively. All potentials reported in this work have been converted to the RHE scale. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Effect of pyrolysis temperatures on the mononuclear iron catalysts Fig. 1 shows the typical preparation procedure of the mononuclear iron catalysts, through a facial two-step method. In the first step, the functional groups (carboxylic or hydroxyl groups) present on the acid-treated carbon can serve as active site for chemical adsorption of FeCl3 and melamine through electrostatic interaction [27]. Then, their hybrids are encapsulated by SiO2 layer. In the second step, the silica-assisted hybrids are annealed at different temperatures, then followed by a leaching treatment with HF solution to remove the coated SiO2. During the pyrolysis stage, the silica layer can exhibit a significant confinement effect for the Fe atoms, which are more effectively transformed into highly dispersed Fe site coordinated with adjacent nitrogen atoms instead of inactive phases such as metallic Fe or its carbides [25]. In our previous report, we identified silica as an independent factor contributing to formation of the pure Fe-N-C catalyst without Fe-based impurity phases [26]. Even with the aid of the protective silica layer, the pyrolysis temperature may strongly affect the chemical structure, oxidation state of the mononuclear iron catalysts. To comprehensively study this effect, different pyrolysis temperatures (700, 800, 900 and 1000℃) are employed in the synthesis of the mononuclear Fe catalysts. Their morphologies were first examined by TEM, as shown in Fig. 2 . All these catalysts are mainly composed of isolated carbon blank nanoparticles with sizes ranging from 30 to 40 nm. However, with increasing the pyrolysis temperature, the morphologies of these catalysts change significantly. For the catalysts fabricated at 700 and 800℃ (Fig. 1A and B), besides the carbon nanoparticles, no obvious Fe-based particles (such as Fe3C, FexOy, or metallic Fe phase) can be found in these catalysts, because the silica layer can restrict the free migration of iron species, avoiding the formation of these particles during the pyrolysis [25,28]. In this case, iron atoms will be well dispersed along the carbon framework and probably act with gaseous substances containing nitrogen atoms to form the mononuclear Fe-related species (Fe-N4) instead of Fe-based particles [29,30]. When pyrolysis temperature increases to 900 and 1000℃, the resultant catalysts exhibit a slightly altered structure as shown in Fig. 2C and D; some crystalline nanoparticles in the range of 40–50 nm with darker contrast are clearly observed. The large nanoparticles are well crystallized with a lattice distance of 0.201 nm which are assigned to (031) lattice plane of the Fe3C, preliminarily proving the formation of Fe3C particles. The formation of Fe3C is likely due to the structure change of the mononuclear Fe catalyst at elevated temperature, in which the bond between iron and nitrogen atoms is broken. After the destruction of Fe-N structure, the Fe atoms can further migrate and agglomerate to react with carbon atoms across the silica shell at high temperature, leading to the generation of large-sized Fe3C nanoparticles. Furthermore, besides the formation of Fe3C particles, the HRTEM images of the catalysts obtained 900 and 1000℃ clearly exhibit that some highly graphitic carbon shells with interplanar spacing of about 0.34 nm are grown on the surface of these nanoparticles because of the catalytic manner of Fe3C particles as suggested by previous reports [31–33]. The above outcomes indicate that the importance in choice of pyrolysis temperature for the final properties of silica-assisted mononuclear iron catalysts. To obtain further insight into the structural change of the silica-assisted mononuclear Fe catalysts (fabricated at different temperature), X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were performed as shown in Fig. 3 A. Two relatively wide diffraction peaks located at 26° and 43° are observed in the catalysts, which are assigned to the (002) and (100) diffraction planes of carbon, respectively. Moreover, as the pyrolysis temperature increases from 700 to 1000 ℃, the (002) diffraction peak of carbon shifts to higher angel direction, illustrating an improvement of graphitization degree in the carbon matrix [5,34]. It can be further confirmed by the Raman spectra. As observed in Fig. 3B, the Raman microscopy reveals the D and G bands of graphitic carbon at 1357 and 1580 cm−1, respectively. The D band correspond to the sp3-bonded carbon while the G band is due to the presence of sp2-bonded carbon atoms in two-dimensional hexagonal graphitic layers [5]. The intensity ratio of the D to G band (ID/IG) is normally employed to express the graphitization of carbon materials. A lower value is associated with a higher degree of graphitization. Through Lorentzian curve-fitting [35], the calculated ID/IG value is decreased from 0.98 to 0.88, indicating the increased degree of graphitization of carbon. Apart from the shifted peak position of carbon with increasing pyrolysis temperature, the catalysts (fabricated at 900 and 1000 ℃) also show a series diffraction peaks attributed to crystal planes of Fe3C (PDF#35-0772). The crystalline structure of the Fe3C species is further illustrated by Raman spectra. As depicted in Fig. 3C, two characteristic peaks in the Raman scattering line are observed at 219 and 284 cm−1, which corresponds respectively to the A1g and Eg symmetric phonon modes of crystalline Fe3C [36,37]. On the contrary, it is noted that no any diffraction peaks or Raman scattering peaks corresponding to Fe3C phase are detected in Cat-700 and 800, excluding the presence of any crystalline particles of Fe3C. According to previous reports [29], the Fe atoms in the mononuclear Fe catalysts may be fixed by coordination with N atoms, forming the Fe-N4 moieties. Thus, we conclude that an appropriate pyrolysis temperature (700 and 800℃) is indispensable condition for the synthesis of the desired catalyst with Fe-N moieties. Furthermore, these Fe-N moieties can be partially or completely destroyed and transferred to Fe3C species above 800 ℃. To capture the evolution of the Fe-N moieties during pyrolysis, the N1 s X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was further conducted. As depicted in Fig. 3D, the N 1s spectra present four well fitted peaks at 398.9, 399.8, 401.1 and 402.9 eV cooresponding to pyridinic N, FeN, pyrrolic N and graphitic N, respectively [38–40]. For the mononuclear Fe catalysts, the FeN groups contributes largely to improve the ORR activity [41]. The quantitative values of different types of nitrogen can be calculated by the integral area of the corresponding peaks. As observed in Table 1 , with increasing the pyrolysis temperature in the range from 700 to 1000 ℃, the correspondingly contents of the FeN groups increase first and then decrease. Among all the tested catalysts, the one carbonized at 800 ℃ exhibits the highest Fe-N content. The reason for the maximun content of FeN bond may be associated with the maximun chemical contact area formed on the surface of carbon matrix, depending on dispersion of the atomic Fe. When the catalyst was heat-treated above 800 ℃, the atomic Fe tend to agglomerate and form bulk Fe3C particles, which leads to the destroy of the FeN bond and then the covalent bond content rapidly decreases. 2.2 ORR activity of the catalysts prepared at different pyrolysis temperature To investigate the effect of pyrolysis temperature on the ORR activities of the mononuclear iron catalysts, rotating-disk electrode (RDE) measurement was performed in 1 M NaOH solution with a continuous supply of oxygen at room temperature. Fig. 4 A shows the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves of the mononuclear iron catalysts fabricated at different temperatures. For comparison, a commercial Pt/C catalyst (20 wt% Pt, relative to carbon) is also tested under the same condition. As indicated in Fig. 4B and C, the measured half-wave potential (E1/2) and mass-specific activities (MSA, Ik normalized by the catalysts mass loading) follow the order: Cat-800> Pt/C > Cat-700> Cat-900> Cat-1000. Among the tested catalysts, the mononuclear iron catalyst synthesized at 800℃ shows the highest catalytic activity based on E1/2 values (0.90) and the mass-specific activity (5.2 mA/mg), at 0.9 vs RHE. This increase in ORR activity is presumably causally connected with an increase in FeN groups (Fig. 3D) [40,41]. As the pyrolysis temperature increased to 900 and 1000℃, the E1/2 value and the magnitude of the mass-specific activity decreased as a result of structural destruction of mononuclear Fe site and the formation of Fe3C nanoparticles entrapped in carbon shells. Some researchers proposed that the Fe3C particles entrapped in carbon shells cannot directly participate in the ORR process [15,42]. Moreover, the large particles may influence the catalyst with a low surface area, reducing access for O2 molecules to the catalyst surface. Tafel slope is further calculated to give a deep insight into the reaction kinetics on the mononuclear iron catalysts. As shown in Fig. 4D, at the low overpotential region, linear regressions of the catalysts show that the slopes are all close to 60 mV dec−1 except for Catalyst-1000 where the slope is close to 74 mV dec−1. Such Tafel behavior has also been revealed for the commercial Pt/C catalyst [41]. As observed, the Tafel slope of Cat-800 is ˜61.9 mV dec−1, which is nearly close to that of the Pt/C (˜60 mV dec−1), suggesting that the catalytic mechanism of ORR on Cat-800 resembles that on Pt (˜62.7 mV dec−1). That is, at the low overpotential region, the reaction rate of Fe-N-C catalyst was mainly controlled by the pseudo two-electron reduction reaction, involving the electron transfer from central Fe sites to oxygen molecule and the OO bond breaking [41]. In addition, at 0.90 V, Cat-800 showed much higher kinetic current densities than those of other Fe-N-C catalysts, confirming fast reaction kinetics of the Cat-800 for the ORR. To further probe the ORR pathway over the mononuclear iron catalysts, rotating ring-disk (RRDE) measurements were conducted in O2-saturated 1 M NaOH solution. Based on the data in Fig. 5 A, the electron transfer number per O2 (n) and the percentage of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) produced during the ORR process can be calculated by the following formulas: (1) n = 4 I d I d + I r N - 1 (2) H 2 O 2 % = 200 I r I r + N I d Where Ir , Id and N are the ring current, disk current and the RRDE collection efficiency (0.37 in the present work), respectively. The calculated electron transferred number (n) and H2O2 percentage are plotted as a function of electrode potential (from 0.3 V to 0.9 V vs. RHE), as shown in Fig. 5B. Obviously, it can been seen that the Cat-700 and Cat-800 catalysts can catalyze a one-step four-electron dominated ORR processes (n = 3.7–3.9), giving much less H2O2 yields (around 15%), which is alomost equal to that of commerical Pt/C. In contrast, the overall electron transfer numbers for Cat-900 and Cat-1000 are in the range of 2.9–3.5, with the corresponding percentages of H2O2 being 40–50%. Thus, it can be inferred that the ORR on Cat-900 and Cat-1000 is a mixed process of 2- and 4-electron transfer pathway. Previous works suggested that the favorite ORR process is the four-electron transfer process from O2 to OH− rather than to H2O2 [43,44]. Based on the preceding results, the mononuclear iron catalyst fabricated at 800℃ could be selected as the best catalyst for ORR. Besides the high electro-activity, the long-term stability is also a key parameter for high-performance ORR electrocatalyst. So, we use the current-time (i-t) chronoamperometric measurement to evaluate the stability of the Cat-800 toward ORR. As observed from Fig. 5C, the decay in the relative currents of oxygen reduction on the Cat-800 and Pt/C catalysts is remarkably different. After continuous operation for 10000 s, the mononuclear iron catalyst presents low attenuation with high current retention of 96.5%. However, the commercial Pt/C loses 12% of its initial current value, as shown in Fig. 5D. The comparison of i-t curves reveals that the mononuclear iron catalyst is electrochemically more stable compared to the commercial Pt/C catalyst in the alkaline medium. The excellent performance of this mononuclear Fe catalyst fabricated at 800℃ makes it a promising inexpensive electrocatalyst for ORR in alkaline media. 2.3 Structure of mononuclear Iron in catalysts For these sinthyesized mononuclear iron catalysts, the formed Fe-N moieties with unfilled dz2 orbitals can promote the chemical adsorption and dissociation of O2 molecule [20,40,45]. The abundant FeN bond could be a vital factor for enhancing the electrochemical performance, and act as greatly efficient active sites for enhancing the catalytic activities [19,46]. In attempt to further understand the nature of Fe-N moieties, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) at Fe k-edge, a sensitive characterization for identifying nanocrystalline species, was conducted to analyze the coordination environment of iron. Fig. 6 A shows the Fourier-transformed k3-weighted EXAFS spectra at the Fe K edge, which yield precise metal-ligand distances in the catalyst. The catalysts prepared at 700 and 800 ℃ present a prominent peak at 1.47 Å, which is due to the formation of Fe-N4 coordination, resembling the FePc reference sample [20,47]. Nevertheless, the structural features of Cat-900 and Cat-1000 significantly differ from those of the catalyst fabricated at 700 ℃ and at 800 ℃, as suggested by the weak but still recognizable peak at 1.47 Å. Besides, a broad peak at 2.2 Å arising from the Fe-Fe coordination of Fe carbides (Fe3C) can be clearly observed in these catalysts [47]. It offers a direct proof that with increasing the pyrolysis temperature, the FeN bond in the monuclear iron catalyst is inevitably broken and subsequently react with free C atoms, leading to the generation of Fe3C nanoparticles. From the XANES spectra depicted in Fig. 6B, the similarity in pre-edge energy at 7117 eV is evident in the reference FePc and mononclear Fe catalysts catalysts (fabricated at 700 and 800 ℃), indicating a silmilar Fe-N4 configuration [20,47]. It is significantly different from that of Cat-900 and Cat-1000, which show more metallic chatacter. Moreover, the intensity and position of the characteristic peaks in the mononuclear iron catalysts (fabricated at 700 and 800 ℃) have changed. Compared with the FePc reference sample, the characteristic Peak C at 7131 eV increased, the peaks at 7137 (Peak D) depressed and the peak E at 7160 Å moved to lower energie field, indicating the formation of non-planar Fe-N4 moieties in the mononuclear iron catalyst [48]. In order to gain more information about the electronic sturcture of central Fe in the Fe-N4 moieties, the Fe 2p X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was conducted as shown in Fig. 6C. However, the spectra of the catalysts have a high noise to signal ratio due to its low iron content, and therefore was not deconvoluted. Hence, we analyzed the XANES spectra of Fe L-edge because it results from electronic transition between 2p level and the largely unoccupied 3d electron state, which are highly sensitive to the valence and spin states of the probed Fe atom [49]. As observed from Fig. 6D, two main spectral features are resoved at 710 eV (L3-edge) and 723 eV (L2-edge) regions for all catalysts. The former comes from transitions from Fe 2p3/2 to Fe 3d states, while the latter involves transition from Fe 2p1/2 to Fe 3d states [50]. From the overall spectral shape, especially the L3-edge, it can be concluded that there are structural differences between these mononuclear iron catalysts (fabricated at different pyrolysis temperature). First of all, the mean oxidation state of Fe in these mononuclear iron catalysts (fabricated at 700 and 800 ℃) than that the catalysts (fabricated at 900 and1000 ℃), as evidenced by the absorption edge position. Secondly, a splitting of the L3 peaks is observed, which corresponds to metal-ligand electronic interactions. With the increased pyrolysis temperature, the intensity of the splitting peaks exhibits visible changes. The mononuclear Fe catalysts (fabricated at 700 and 800 ℃) contains only one peak at the energy of 708.5 eV, indicating the existence of divalent ions Fe(II) in the Fe-N4 moieties [18,22,48,51]. When the temperature was further elevated to 900 °C and 1000 °C, trivalent ions Fe(III)appear in these spectra owing to the generation of Fe3C nanoparticles. Based on the aforementioned analysis, it is resonable to expect that the ORR performance of the mononuclear iron catalysts should depend on the high percentage of nonplanar Fe(II)N4 groups. In order to understand the coorelation ship between Fe(II)-N4 sites and ORR activity, we plotted the half-wave potentials of the catalysts as a function of the contents of Fe(II)-N moieties. With increasing the Fe(II)-N content, the corresponding half-wave potential is positively shifted, as shown in Fig. 7 A. A linear trend is observed for the half-wave potentials and contens of the Fe(II)-N moieties in the monunclear Fe catalysts, suggesting that the ORR activity is significantly dependent on the Fe(II)N bond. Moreover, the mass-specific activities also show a silmilar linear tendency. These results illustrate that the mononuclear iron catalysts fabricated at 800 °C with 21.6% nonplanar Fe(II)-N4 moieties display highest ORR activity. In our previous study [27], we have found that the Fe(II) center in the nonplanar Fe(II)-N4 moieties is active sites for oxygen reduction in the Fe-N-C catalysts. Along with the process of ORR on the central Fe(II), the structure of Fe(II)-N4 moieties will switch from non-planer to planer, which may shorten Fe(III)N bond distance and decrease electronic density of the iron, thereby facilitate the axial adsorption of active O2. 3 Conclusions In summary, we have successfully synthesized a series of mononuclear iron catalysts at different pyrolysis temperature by using silica as the protective layer. During the high-temperature pyrolysis process, the formation of the catalytically active Fe-N4 sites is strongly influenced by the pyrolysis temperature and, in turn, the ORR activity of the catalysts is also controlled by the content and non-planar structure of the active sites. Among the catalysts, the resultant Cat-800 with highest content of Fe-N4 moieties exhibits a significantly enhanced ORR activity, which is surprisingly superior to that of the commercial Pt/C. The remarkably enhanced ORR activity can be attributed to the easily switching behavior of the out-of-plane Fe(II) to in-of-plane Fe(III) ions in the Fe-N4 structure, caused by an electron back-donation between these iron atoms coordinated with N atoms in the mononuclear Fe catalysts. This study may open a new route for rational design and synthesis of efficient mononuclear iron electrocatalysts towards the ORR. coredata.dc:description: As a low-cost nonprecious metal-based catalyst, the mononuclear iron embedded in nitrogen-doped carbons has been regarded as one type of the best electrocatalytic materials for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Herein, we proposed a silica-protective-layer assisted strategy for fabricating the catalysts with mononuclear iron site coordinated with adjacent nitrogen and carbon atoms, through high temperature pyrolysis of melamine, carbon black and FeCl3. At 800 °C, the fabricated catalyst features completely atomic level iron-nitrogen-carbon catalysts without Fe-based phases. In concentrated 1 M NaOH solution, this catalyst displays a remarkably improved catalytic activity with half-wave potential of 0.90 V. The mass activity of catalyst can reach 1.06 times that of commercial Pt/C (20 wt%, Pt). The correlation of the mononuclear iron composition and coordination structure with the promoted ORR kinetics was discussed in detail. The superior activity can be attributed to lots of the mononuclear iron moieties with a non-planar Fe(II)-N4 structure and increased surface area of the as-synthesized heterogeneous catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Mononuclear iron-dependent electrocatalytic activity of metal-nitrogen-carbon catalysts for efficient oxygen reduction reaction
